## What is Git?

Git is a **distributed version control system** (DVCS)

::: {.incremental}
- Tracks changes to files over time
- Enables collaboration among multiple developers
- Allows reverting to specific versions
- Works with both local and remote repositories
- Created by Linus Torvalds in 2005
:::

::: {.notes}
Git is fundamentally different from older centralized version control systems like SVN. The core idea is every developer has a complete copy of the repository history locally.
:::

## Git vs GitHub

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
### Git
- Version control **system**
- Command-line tool
- Runs locally
- Open source
- Works offline
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
### GitHub
- Hosting **platform**
- Web interface
- Cloud-based
- Microsoft-owned
- Requires internet
- Alternatives such as GitLab exist
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note}
Other platforms: GitLab, Bitbucket, Gitea, etc.
:::





# Getting Started
## Installation

**Download from:** [git-scm.com/downloads](https://git-scm.com/downloads)

**Or install via package manager:**

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Linux (Debian/Ubuntu):**
```bash
sudo apt update
sudo apt install git
```

**Linux (Fedora/RHEL):**
```bash
sudo dnf install git
```

**Linux (Arch):**
```bash
sudo pacman -S git
```
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**macOS (Homebrew):**
```bash
brew install git
```

**macOS (Xcode):**
```bash
xcode-select --install
```

**Windows:**
- Download installer from git-scm.com
- Or use: `winget install Git.Git`
:::
:::





## Verify Installation

**Verify installation:**
```bash
git --version
```

Expected output (example):
```
git version 2.45.0
```

::: {.callout-tip}
As of 2025, Git 2.34+ is required for SSH commit signing. Make sure you're on a recent version.
:::






## Initial Configuration

Set your identity (required):

```bash
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
```

View your configuration:

```bash
git config --list
```

::: {.callout-tip}
The `--global` flag applies settings to all repositories on your machine. Omit it to configure a specific repository.
:::












# Core Concepts
## Repository Basics

**Repository** = A version-controlled project

::: {.incremental}
- **Local repository**: On your machine (`.git` directory)
- **Remote repository**: Hosted on GitHub, GitLab, etc.
- **Working directory**: Your actual project files
- **Staging area**: Files prepared for commit
:::





## Creating a Repository
### New repository
```bash
mkdir myproject
cd myproject
git init
```

Creates a hidden `.git` directory for tracking changes

### Clone existing repository
```bash
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git
```





## Checking Status

See the current state of your repository:

```bash
git status
```

Shows:

::: {.incremental}
- Which branch you're on
- Staged changes (ready to commit)
- Unstaged changes (modified but not staged)
- Untracked files (new files Git doesn't know about)
:::





# The Git Workflow
## Three-Stage Architecture

```{mermaid}
%%| fig-width: 10
flowchart LR
    A[Working Directory] -->|git add| B[Staging Area]
    B -->|git commit| C[Local Repository]
    C -->|git push| D[Remote Repository]
    D -->|git pull| A
```

## Staging Changes

Add specific file:
```bash
git add filename.txt
```

Add multiple files:
```bash
git add file1.js file2.css
```

Add all changes:
```bash
git add .
```

::: {.callout-warning}
Be careful with `git add .` - review what you're adding with `git status` first!
:::







## Committing Changes

Create a snapshot with a message:

```bash
git commit -m "Add user authentication feature"
```

::: {.callout-tip title="Good Commit Messages"}
- Use present tense: "Add feature" not "Added feature"
- Be descriptive but concise
- First line < 50 characters
- Add details in body if needed
:::





## Viewing History

See all commits:
```bash
git log
```

Compact view:
```bash
git log --oneline
```

With graph visualization:
```bash
git log --graph --oneline --all
```











# Branching and Merging
## Why Branches?

::: {.incremental}
- Work on features without affecting main code
- Experiment safely
- Collaborate without conflicts
- Organize different development streams
:::

```{mermaid}
%%| fig-width: 8
gitGraph
    commit
    commit
    branch feature
    checkout feature
    commit
    commit
    checkout main
    merge feature
    commit
```

## Branch Operations

Create a branch:
```bash
git branch feature-login
```

Create and switch to branch:
```bash
git checkout -b feature-login
# or (Git 2.23+)
git switch -c feature-login
```

List branches:
```bash
git branch
```





## Switching Branches

Old way:
```bash
git checkout main
```

New way (Git 2.23+):
```bash
git switch main
```

::: {.callout-note}
`git switch` was introduced to make branch operations clearer, separating it from `checkout`'s other uses.
:::







## Merging Branches

1. Switch to target branch (usually `main`):
```bash
git switch main
```

2. Merge the feature branch:
```bash
git merge feature-login
```

3. Delete the merged branch:
```bash
git branch -d feature-login
```





## Merge Conflicts

When Git can't automatically merge:

```bash
<<<<<<< HEAD
Current branch content
=======
Incoming branch content
>>>>>>> feature-branch
```

**Resolution steps:**

1. Open conflicted files
2. Choose which changes to keep
3. Remove conflict markers
4. Stage the resolved files: `git add filename`
5. Complete the merge: `git commit`








# Remote Repositories
## Remote Operations

Add a remote:
```bash
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

View remotes:
```bash
git remote -v
```

Remove a remote:
```bash
git remote remove origin
```






## Pushing Changes

Push to remote:
```bash
git push origin main
```

Set upstream (track remote branch):
```bash
git push -u origin main
```

After setting upstream, just use:
```bash
git push
```








## Pulling Changes

Fetch and merge changes:
```bash
git pull origin main
```

::: {.callout-important}
`git pull` = `git fetch` + `git merge`

Use `git fetch` to see changes without merging them immediately.
:::








## Pull with Rebase

To keep a linear history:

```bash
git pull --rebase origin main
```

This applies your commits on top of remote changes instead of creating a merge commit.

::: {.callout-tip}
Use rebase for personal branches, merge for shared branches.
:::








# Setting Up SSH for GitHub
## Why Use SSH?

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**SSH Benefits**
- No password prompts
- More secure than HTTPS
- Encrypted connection
- Key-based authentication
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**HTTPS Drawbacks**
- Requires Personal Access Token
- Token management needed
- Less convenient
- Token can expire
:::
:::

::: {.callout-note}
GitHub deprecated password authentication in August 2021. Use SSH or Personal Access Tokens.
:::









## Checking for Existing SSH Keys

First, check if you already have SSH keys:

```bash
ls -la ~/.ssh
```

Look for files like:
- `id_ed25519` and `id_ed25519.pub` (Ed25519 - recommended)
- `id_rsa` and `id_rsa.pub` (RSA - older)

::: {.callout-tip}
Ed25519 keys are recommended in 2025 - they're more secure and faster than RSA.
:::









## Generating a New SSH Key

**Recommended (Ed25519):**
```bash
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your_email@example.com"
```

**For older systems (RSA):**
```bash
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "your_email@example.com"
```

When prompted:

1. Press Enter to accept default location
2. Enter a secure passphrase (recommended)
3. Confirm passphrase










## Adding SSH Key to ssh-agent

**macOS/Linux:**
```bash
# Start ssh-agent
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"

# Add your key (Ed25519 example)
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
```

**macOS with Keychain:**
```bash
ssh-add --apple-use-keychain ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
```

**Windows (PowerShell as Admin):**
```bash
# Start ssh-agent
Get-Service ssh-agent | Set-Service -StartupType Automatic
Start-Service ssh-agent

# Add key
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
```













## Adding SSH Key to GitHub

**Copy your public key:**

```bash
# macOS
pbcopy < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

# Linux (with xclip)
xclip -sel clip < ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub

# Windows (Git Bash)
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub | clip

# Or just display and copy manually
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
```










## Adding to GitHub (cont.)

1. Go to GitHub.com → **Settings**
2. Click **SSH and GPG keys** (left sidebar)
3. Click **New SSH key**
4. Add a descriptive title (e.g., "Personal Laptop")
5. Select key type: **Authentication Key**
6. Paste your public key
7. Click **Add SSH key**








## Testing Your SSH Connection

```bash
ssh -T git@github.com
```

Expected output:
```
Hi username! You've successfully authenticated, 
but GitHub does not provide shell access.
```

::: {.callout-important}
This is normal - GitHub doesn't allow shell access, only Git operations.
:::








## Using SSH URLs

When cloning, use SSH format:

```bash
# SSH format (recommended)
git clone git@github.com:username/repo.git

# NOT HTTPS format
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git
```

**Convert existing repo to SSH:**
```bash
git remote set-url origin git@github.com:username/repo.git
```











## SSH Configuration (Optional)

Create/edit `~/.ssh/config`:

```
Host github.com
  HostName github.com
  User git
  IdentityFile ~/.ssh/id_ed25519
  IdentitiesOnly yes
```

Benefits:

- Specify which key to use
- Multiple GitHub accounts support
- Custom settings per host













# Making Your First Contribution
## Fork → Clone → Edit → PR Workflow

This is the standard workflow for contributing to open-source projects:

```{mermaid}
%%| fig-width: 10
flowchart LR
    A[Fork Repository] --> B[Clone to Local]
    B --> C[Create Branch]
    C --> D[Make Changes]
    D --> E[Commit Changes]
    E --> F[Push to Fork]
    F --> G[Create Pull Request]
```

::: {.notes}
Based on the "First Contributions" project - helping beginners make their first open-source contribution.
:::






## Step 1: Fork the Repository

**On GitHub:**
1. Navigate to the repository you want to contribute to
2. Click the **Fork** button (top right)
3. This creates a copy in your GitHub account

::: {.callout-note}
Forking creates an independent copy - you can experiment freely!
:::






## Step 2: Clone Your Fork

```bash
# Clone YOUR fork (not the original)
git clone git@github.com:YOUR-USERNAME/repository-name.git

# Example
git clone git@github.com:jane-doe/first-contributions.git

# Enter the repository
cd repository-name
```

::: {.callout-tip}
Use SSH URLs for easier authentication!
:::






## Step 3: Create a Branch

```bash
# Create and switch to a new branch
git switch -c your-branch-name

# Example with descriptive name
git switch -c add-jane-doe
```

**For older Git versions:**
```bash
git checkout -b your-branch-name
```

::: {.callout-important}
Always create a new branch for your changes - never work directly on `main`!
:::







## Step 4: Make Your Changes

1. Edit the files you need to change
2. Save your work

**Check what changed:**
```bash
git status
```

Shows:

- Modified files
- New files
- Deleted files








## Step 5: Commit Your Changes

```bash
# Stage your changes
git add filename.txt
# or stage all changes
git add .

# Commit with descriptive message
git commit -m "Add Jane Doe to contributors list"
```

::: {.callout-tip}
Write clear commit messages describing *what* and *why* you changed something.
:::









## Step 6: Push to Your Fork

```bash
# Push your branch to YOUR fork on GitHub
git push -u origin your-branch-name

# Example
git push -u origin add-jane-doe
```

The `-u` flag sets up tracking so you can use `git push` next time.










## Step 7: Create Pull Request

**On GitHub:**

1. Go to **your fork** on GitHub
2. You'll see: "**Compare & pull request**" button
3. Click it
4. Review your changes
5. Write a description of what you did
6. Click "**Create pull request**"

## Pull Request Best Practices

::: {.incremental}
- **Clear title**: Describe what the PR does
- **Good description**: Explain why the change is needed
- **Link issues**: Reference related issues (#123)
- **Small changes**: Keep PRs focused and manageable
- **Follow guidelines**: Check CONTRIBUTING.md
- **Be patient**: Wait for review feedback
- **Respond to feedback**: Address reviewer comments
:::










## After Your PR is Merged

**Clean up your local repository:**

```bash
# Switch back to main
git switch main

# Pull the updated main branch
git pull upstream main
# or if no upstream
git pull origin main

# Delete your feature branch (optional)
git branch -d add-jane-doe
```












## Keeping Your Fork Updated

Add the original repository as "upstream":

```bash
# Add upstream remote (one time only)
git remote add upstream git@github.com:ORIGINAL-OWNER/REPO.git

# Fetch changes from upstream
git fetch upstream

# Merge upstream changes into your main
git switch main
git merge upstream/main

# Push updates to your fork
git push origin main
```










## Common Contribution Workflow Issues

**Merge conflicts:**
- Occur when main branch changed since you forked
- Update your branch: `git merge main`
- Resolve conflicts in files
- Commit the resolution

**PR rejected:**
- Read feedback carefully
- Make requested changes
- Commit and push to same branch
- PR updates automatically













# Signed Commits
## Why Sign Commits?

::: {.incremental}
- **Authentication**: Prove you made the commit
- **Integrity**: Verify commits haven't been tampered with
- **Trust**: Essential for security-critical projects
- **Accountability**: Prevent impersonation
:::

::: {.callout-note}
Anyone with push rights can commit as any author. Signing prevents this!
:::











## Signing Methods (2025)

Git supports **three** methods:

::: {.incremental}
1. **GPG** (GNU Privacy Guard)
   - Most widely supported
   - Works on all platforms
   - More complex setup

2. **SSH** (Git 2.34+)
   - Simpler setup
   - Reuse existing SSH keys
   - Supported by GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket

3. **S/MIME**
   - Corporate environments
   - Certificate-based
:::

::: {.notes}
SSH signing is a Git feature, not GitHub-specific. GitHub/GitLab verify and display signatures.
:::







## GPG Signing Setup

**Generate a GPG key:**
```bash
gpg --full-generate-key
```

**List your keys:**
```bash
gpg --list-secret-keys --keyid-format=long
```

**Configure Git:**
```bash
git config --global user.signingkey YOUR_KEY_ID
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
```

















## Exporting GPG Public Key

**Export for GitHub/GitLab:**
```bash
gpg --armor --export YOUR_KEY_ID
```

Copy the output and add to:
- GitHub: Settings → SSH and GPG keys
- GitLab: Preferences → GPG Keys












## SSH Signing Setup

**Tell Git to use SSH:**
```bash
git config --global gpg.format ssh
git config --global user.signingkey ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
```

**Enable automatic signing:**
```bash
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
```

Add your public key to GitHub/GitLab as a **Signing Key** (not just authentication)

::: {.callout-tip}
SSH signing is much simpler! No GPG agent needed.
:::










## Making Signed Commits

**Manual signing:**
```bash
git commit -S -m "Signed commit message"
```

**Automatic signing** (recommended):
```bash
git config --global commit.gpgsign true
# Now all commits are signed automatically
```

**Verify signatures:**
```bash
git log --show-signature
```









## Signature Verification

On GitHub/GitLab, signed commits show:

- ✅ **Verified** - Valid signature
- ⚠️ **Unverified** - No signature or can't verify
- ❌ **Invalid** - Signature doesn't match

::: {.callout-note}
Verification requires your public key to be uploaded to the platform.
:::

# Advanced Topics

## .gitignore

Ignore files Git shouldn't track:

```bash
# Create .gitignore file
touch .gitignore
```

Example contents:
```
# Build outputs
*.log
build/
dist/

# Dependencies
node_modules/
venv/

# Environment files
.env
secrets.json

# OS files
.DS_Store
Thumbs.db
```












## Removing Tracked Files

If you accidentally committed a file that should be ignored:

```bash
git rm --cached filename
```

Then add it to `.gitignore` and commit:

```bash
echo "filename" >> .gitignore
git add .gitignore
git commit -m "Stop tracking filename"
```












## Stashing Changes

Save changes without committing:

```bash
git stash
```

List stashes:
```bash
git stash list
```

Reapply stashed changes:
```bash
git stash apply
# or
git stash pop  # applies and removes from stash
```











## Tagging Releases

Create an annotated tag:
```bash
git tag -a v1.0.0 -m "Release version 1.0.0"
```

Push tags to remote:
```bash
git push origin v1.0.0
# or push all tags
git push --tags
```

List tags:
```bash
git tag
```












## Cherry-Pick

Apply a specific commit to current branch:

```bash
git cherry-pick <commit-hash>
```

Useful for:
- Applying bug fixes to multiple branches
- Selectively bringing in features

::: {.callout-warning}
Use sparingly - can duplicate commits and complicate history
:::













## Undoing Changes

**Unstage a file:**
```bash
git restore --staged filename
```

**Discard working directory changes:**
```bash
git restore filename
```

**Undo last commit (keep changes):**
```bash
git reset --soft HEAD~1
```

**Undo last commit (discard changes):**
```bash
git reset --hard HEAD~1
```










## Finding Lost Commits

Git keeps a history of everything:

```bash
git reflog
```

Recover a lost commit:
```bash
git checkout <commit-hash>
# or create a branch from it
git checkout -b recovered-branch <commit-hash>
```













# Workflows and Best Practices
## Common Workflows

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="50%"}
**Feature Branch Workflow**
- Main branch always stable
- Each feature in own branch
- Merge via pull requests
- Code review before merge
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Trunk-Based Development**
- All work on main branch
- Short-lived feature branches
- Continuous integration
- Feature flags for WIP
:::
:::

::: {.notes}
Gitflow (develop/main branches) has fallen out of favor for most teams. Trunk-based is now considered best practice for CI/CD.
:::











## Commit Best Practices

::: {.incremental}
1. **Commit often** - Small, logical units of work
2. **Write clear messages** - Explain *why*, not just *what*
3. **One concern per commit** - Keep commits focused
4. **Test before committing** - Don't break the build
5. **Sign your commits** - Especially for public projects
:::











## Branch Naming Conventions

Use prefixes for clarity:

```
feature/user-authentication
bugfix/login-error
hotfix/security-patch
release/v2.0.0
```

::: {.callout-tip}
Agree on conventions with your team and stick to them!
:::

## Pull Request Best Practices

::: {.incremental}
- Keep PRs small (< 400 lines changed)
- Provide clear description
- Link to issues/tickets
- Request specific reviewers
- Respond to feedback promptly
- Update branch before merging
:::















# Example Workflows
## Basic Workflow

```bash
# 1. Create project
mkdir myproject && cd myproject
git init

# 2. Create files
echo "# My Project" > README.md
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit"

# 3. Connect to remote
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/myproject.git
git push -u origin main
```

## Feature Branch Workflow

```bash
# 1. Start new feature
git switch -c feature-login

# 2. Make changes
echo "Login code..." > login.js
git add login.js
git commit -S -m "Add login functionality"

# 3. Push and create PR
git push -u origin feature-login
# Then create Pull Request on GitHub

# 4. After PR approved
git switch main
git pull
git branch -d feature-login
```












## Hotfix Workflow

```bash
# 1. Create hotfix branch from main
git switch main
git switch -c hotfix-security-patch

# 2. Fix the issue
# ... make changes ...
git add .
git commit -S -m "Fix security vulnerability"

# 3. Merge to main and develop
git switch main
git merge hotfix-security-patch
git push

# 4. Tag the release
git tag -a v1.0.1 -m "Security patch"
git push --tags

# 5. Clean up
git branch -d hotfix-security-patch
```















# Troubleshooting
## Common Issues

**Detached HEAD State**
```bash
# You're not on a branch!
git switch -c new-branch-name
# or
git switch main
```

**Merge Conflicts**
```bash
# After resolving conflicts in files:
git add .
git commit
```












## Authentication Issues

**HTTPS authentication:**
- Use Personal Access Tokens (not passwords)
- GitHub deprecated password authentication in 2021

**SSH authentication:**
```bash
# Generate SSH key
ssh-keygen -t ed25519 -C "your@email.com"

# Add to ssh-agent
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
ssh-add ~/.ssh/id_ed25519

# Copy public key to GitHub
cat ~/.ssh/id_ed25519.pub
```















## Large Repositories

**Clone with shallow history:**
```bash
git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

**Sparse checkout** (specific directories only):
```bash
git clone --filter=blob:none --sparse https://github.com/user/repo.git
cd repo
git sparse-checkout add path/to/dir
```
